question: But these deceits have their [MASK], and we advance to them.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Every thing which we call culture,--our sciences, art, and the perfection of the pleasant thing's of life,--all these are attempts to deceive the moral requirements of man; every thing that is called hygiene and medicine, is an attempt to deceive the natural physical demands of human nature.
next_sentence: "If such be the real human life, then it is better not to live at all," says the reigning and extremely fashionable philosophy of Schopenhauer and Hartmann.

question: Every thing which we call culture ,--our sciences, art, and the perfection of the pleasant thing's of life ,--all these are attempts to deceive the moral requirements of man; every thing that is called [MASK] and medicine, is an attempt to deceive the natural physical demands of human nature.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: We have arranged for ourselves a life that is repugnant both to the moral and the physical nature of man, and all the powers of our intelligence we concentrate upon assuring man that this is the most natural life possible.
next_sentence: But these deceits have their bounds, and we advance to them.

question: And, in order to [MASK] every thing from the beginning, you must look through microscopes at the movements of amoebae, and cells in worms, or, with still greater composure, believe in every thing that men with a diploma of infallibility shall say to you about them.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The true scientific method is this: If you wish to know in what the destiny and the welfare of all mankind and of all the world consists, you must, first of all, cease to listen to the voices of your conscience and of your reason, which present themselves in you and in others like you; you must cease to believe all that the great teachers of mankind have said with regard to your conscience and reason, and you must consider all this as nonsense, and begin all over again.
next_sentence: And as you gaze at the movements of these cells, or read about what others have seen, you must attribute to these cells your own human sensations and calculations as to what they desire, whither they are directing themselves, how they compare and discuss, and to what they have become accustomed; and from these observations (in which there is not a word about an error of thought or of expression) you must deduce a conclusion by analogy as to what you are, what is your destiny, wherein lies the welfare of yourself and of other cells like you.

question: This enumeration and pride of enthusiasm over ourselves and our exploits can be [MASK] in almost any newspaper and popular pamphlet.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: I will not enumerate every thing on which our age thus prides itself.
next_sentence: This enthusiasm over ourselves is often repeated to such a degree that none of us can sufficiently rejoice over ourselves, that we are seriously convinced that art and science have never made such progress as in our own time.

question: You may affirm a [MASK] and interaction between whatever you choose, and, according to evolution, you may affirm, that, out of whatever you please, any other thing that you please may proceed, in a very long period of time.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Every collection of living individuals, which re-act upon each other, and do not destroy each other, may be regarded as organisms, according to their theory.
next_sentence: And the most remarkable thing of all is, that this same identical positive science recognizes the scientific method as the sign of true knowledge, and has itself defined what it designates as the scientific method.

question: But it now appears, that all these great [MASK] in the science and art of the past are no longer of use to us.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: And it is not without reason that mankind has valued and still values them so highly.
next_sentence: Nowadays, scientific and artistic authorities can, in accordance with the law of division of labor, be turned out by factory methods; and, in one decade, more great men have been manufactured in art and science, than have ever been born of such among all nations, since the foundation of the world.

question: In this one act, man [MASK]--if the two things are to be separated--full satisfaction of the bodily and spiritual demands of his nature.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: But if a man excuses himself from this obligation by making other people fulfil it for him, then also he is immediately punished by the annihilation of his mental life; that is to say, of the life which possesses rational thought.
next_sentence: The feeding, clothing, and taking care of himself and his family, constitute the satisfaction of the bodily demands and requirements; and doing the same for other people, constitutes the satisfaction of his spiritual requirements.

question: Science maintains the [MASK] of labor as a unalterable law; it sees that the distribution of wealth, founded on the division of labor, is wrong and ruinous; and it affirms that its activity, which recognizes the division of labor, will lead people to bliss.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: But this unfortunate circumstance is produced by themselves; for this irregular distribution of wealth flows solely from the theory of the division of labor.
next_sentence: The result is, that some people make use of the labor of others; but that, if they shall make use of the labor of others for a very long period of time, and in still larger measure, then this wrongful distribution of wealth, i.e., the use of the labor of others, will come to an end.

question: They do not fulfil it, because out of their [MASK] they have erected a right.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: And it can be understood why the makers of the present arts and sciences have not fulfilled, and cannot fulfil, their vocation.
next_sentence: Scientific and artistic activity, in its real sense, is only fruitful when it knows no rights, but recognizes only obligations.

question: And we have not tamed a single animal since [MASK] times, when all our animals were already domesticated; but the reindeer, the stag, the partridge, the heath-cock, all remain wild.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: We have reckoned up two millions of beetles!
next_sentence: Our botanists have discovered the cell, and in the cell protoplasm, and in that protoplasm still something more, and in that atom yet another thing.

question: It appeared to be busy itself only with [MASK] data.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Precisely this seemed to be the case with the Malthusian theory.
next_sentence: But this was only in appearance.

question: [MASK] of labor always has existed in human communities, and will probably always exist; but the question for us lies not in the fact that it has existed, and that it will exist, but in this ,--how are we to govern ourselves so that this division shall be right?
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: And in precisely the same manner, according to the measure of their folly, do they acquire self-conceit, which deprives them forever of all possibility of return to a simple life of toil, to a simple, clear, and universally human train of reasoning.
next_sentence: But if we take investigation as our rule of action, we by this very act repudiate all rule; then in that case we shall regard as right every division of labor which we shall descry among men, and which appears to us to be right--to which conclusion the prevailing scientific science also leads.

question: Just so man, when he walks, turns, raises, drags, works with his fingers, with his [MASK], with his ears, with his tongue, with his brain ,--only then is he satisfied, only then is he a man.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The bird is so constructed, that it is indispensable that it should fly, walk, peek, combine; and when it does all this, it is satisfied and happy,--then it is a bird.
next_sentence: A man who acknowledges his appointment to labor will naturally strive towards that rotation of labor which is peculiar to him, for the satisfaction of his inward requirements; and he can alter this labor in no other way than when he feels within himself an irresistible summons to some exclusive form of labor, and when the demands of other men for that labor are expressed.

question: And what is to be done with the remaining eleven [MASK]?
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: If any man engaged in intellectual occupations devote five hours every day to his occupation, he will accomplish a fearful amount.
next_sentence: It proved that physical labor not only does not exclude the possibility of mental activity, but that it improves its quality, and encourages it.

question: That which is called science and art, among us, is the product of idle minds and feelings, which have for their object to [MASK] similar idle minds and feelings.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: No matter what people have fixed upon as their vocation and their welfare, science will be the doctrine of this vocation and welfare, and art will be the expression of that doctrine.
next_sentence: Our arts and sciences are incomprehensible, and say nothing to the people, for they have not the welfare of the common people in view.

question: But the division of [MASK] is more profitable.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Only on condition of such a view of labor, and of the natural division of labor arising from it, is that curse which is laid upon our idea of labor abrogated, and does every sort of work becomes always a joy; because a man will either perform that labor which is undoubtedly useful and joyous, and not dull, or he will possess the consciousness of self-abnegation in the fulfilment of more difficult and restricted toil, which he exercises for the good of others.
next_sentence: More profitable for whom?

question: But art, in its capacity of an important human [MASK], disappeared simultaneously with the substitution for the genuine science of destiny and welfare, of the science of any thing you choose to fancy.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Always, down to the most recent times, art has served science and life,--only then was it what has been so highly esteemed of men.
next_sentence: Art has existed among all peoples, and will exist until that which among us is scornfully called religion has come to be considered the only science.

question: We have reckoned up two [MASK] of beetles!
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: We have invented telegraphs, telephones, phonographs; but what advances have we effected in the life, in the labor, of the people?
next_sentence: And we have not tamed a single animal since biblical times, when all our animals were already domesticated; but the reindeer, the stag, the partridge, the heath-cock, all remain wild.

question: According to his theory, it seemed that since humanity is an organism, the knowledge of what man is, and of what should be his relations to the [MASK], was possible only through a knowledge of the features of this organism.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: He, as frequently happens, mistook his pet hypothesis for an axiom, and imagined that his whole theory was erected on the very firmest of foundations.
next_sentence: For the knowledge of these qualities, man is enabled to take observations on other and lower organisms, and to draw conclusions from their life.

question: On the same [MASK], under the features of an organism, you may range whatever you please.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: But surely, this is an empty game of dialectics, and nothing more.
next_sentence: I will take the fist thing that comes into my head.

question: The service of the people by science and art will only be performed when people, [MASK] in the midst of the common folk, and, like the common folk, putting forward no demands, claiming no rights, shall offer to the common folk their scientific and artistic services; the acceptance or rejection of which shall depend wholly on the will of the common folk.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Tell the musician that he should play on the harmonica, and teach the women to sing songs; say to the poet, to the author, that he ought to cast aside his poems and romances, and compose song-books, tales, and stories, comprehensible to the uneducated people,--they will say that you are mad.
next_sentence: It is said that the activity of science and art has aided in the forward march of mankind,--meaning by this activity, that which is now called by that name; which is the same as saying that an unskilled banging of oars on a vessel that is floating with the tide, which merely hinders the progress of the vessel, is assisting the movement of the ship.

question: They wish to think so, and it seems to them that, in point of fact, a perfectly regular exchange of services does take [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: With what confidence people enunciate this!
next_sentence: But we, in our blindness, have so completely lost sight of the responsibility which we have assumed, that we have even forgotten in whose name our labor is prosecuted; and the very people whom we have undertaken to serve have become the objects of our scientific and artistic activity.

question: Christ did not die on the cross in vain; not in [MASK] does the sacrifice of suffering conquer all things.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: It is possible to study out how many beetles there are in the world, to view the spots on the sun, to write romances and operas, without suffering; but it is impossible, without self-sacrifice, to instruct people in their true happiness, which consists solely in renunciation of self and the service of others, and to give strong expression to this doctrine, without self-sacrifice.
next_sentence: But our art and science are provided with certificates and diplomas; and the only anxiety of all men is, how to still better guarantee them, i.e., how to render the service of the people impracticable for them.

question: But we practise something which we call science and art, but it appears that what we do is unnecessary and unintelligible to [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: But, from whatever cause this has come about, the fact remains, that sciences and arts have always existed among mankind, and, when they really did exist, they were useful and intelligible to all the people.
next_sentence: And hence, however beautiful may be the things that we accomplish, we have no right to call them arts and sciences.

question: Again the sole [MASK] is this: that the teacher should live under the conditions of the working-men, and should teach for that compensation which they give him freely and voluntarily.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The government will build the schools, and will make education obligatory, as it is in Europe; but again, surely, the money is taken from the people just the same, and it will be harder to work, and they will have less leisure for work, and there will be no education even by compulsion.
next_sentence: Such is the false course of science, which deprives it of the power of fulfilling its obligation, which is, to serve the people.

question: The class of learned men and artists, which has [MASK], on the fictitious basis of a division of labor, its demands to the right of using the labors of others, cannot co-operate in the success of true science and true art, because a lie cannot bring forth the truth.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Art and science have bestowed much on mankind, but not because their followers formerly possessed on rare occasions (and now possess on every occasion) the possibility of getting rid of labor; but because there have been men of genius, who, without making use of these rights, have led mankind forward.
next_sentence: We have become so accustomed to these, our tenderly reared or weakened representatives of mental labor, that it seems to us horrible that a man of science or an artist should plough or cart manure.

question: [MASK] the artist that he should paint without a studio, model, or costumes, and that he should paint five-kopek pictures, and he will say that that is tantamount to abandoning his art, as he understands it.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: It is as if those two things which are made for each other--the lock and the key--had parted company; they have sprung so far apart, that not even the possibility of uniting them presents itself.
next_sentence: Tell the musician that he should play on the harmonica, and teach the women to sing songs; say to the poet, to the author, that he ought to cast aside his poems and romances, and compose song-books, tales, and stories, comprehensible to the uneducated people,--they will say that you are mad.

question: This assertion was arbitrary, because we have just as much right to admit the existence of a human organism, not subject to [MASK], as we have to admit the existence of any other invisible, fantastic being.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: There was but one error, and that was this,--that the whole edifice was erected on the sand, on the arbitrary and false assertion that humanity is an organism.
next_sentence: This assertion was erroneous, because for the understanding of humanity, i.e., of men, the definition of an organism was incorrectly constructed, while in humanity itself all actual signs of organism,--the centre of feeling or consciousness, are lacking.

question: This is the [MASK] method of ratiocination (wherein lies the difference between the deductive and the inductive method, no one can understand); these are the dogmas of the technological and metaphysical period.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: All at once, a new caste of people makes its appearance, and they say, "All this is nonsense; all this must be abandoned."
next_sentence: Every thing that these men discover by inward experience, and which they communicate to one another, concerning their knowledge of the law of their existence (of their functional activity, according to their own jargon), every thing that the grandest minds of mankind have accomplished in this direction, since the beginning of the world,--all this is nonsense, and has no weight whatever.

question: Humanity, or human [MASK], are the organisms already prepared, or still in process of formation, and which are subservient to all the laws of the evolution of organisms.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The scientific theory is as follows:--  "For the study of the laws of life of human societies, there exists but one indubitable method,--the positive, experimental, critical method  "Only sociology, founded on biology, founded on all the positive sciences, can give us the laws of humanity.
next_sentence: "One of the chief of these laws is the variation of destination among the portions of the organs.

question: If a man who has long been travelling on this false path divines for himself, or is informed by some one, that his course is a mistaken one, but grows alarmed at the idea that he has wandered very far astray and tries to convince himself that he may, possibly, still strike into the right [MASK], then he never will get into it.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: If a man, having entered on the wrong path, assumes that it is the true one, then every step that he takes on that path removes him farther from his goal.
next_sentence: If a man quails before the truth, and, on perceiving it, does not accept it, but does accept a lie for the truth, then he never will learn what he ought to do.

question: Exactly in the same manner science has so arranged this matter, that only wealthy people are able to study [MASK], and teachers, like technologists and physicians, cling to money.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The same is the case with the activity of the teachers of science,--pedagogical teachers.
next_sentence: And this cannot be otherwise, because a school built on a model plan (as a general rule, the more scientifically built the school, the more costly it is), with pivot chains, and globes, and maps, and library, and petty text-books for teachers and scholars and pedagogues, is a sort of thing for which it would be necessary to double the taxes in every village.

question: All this progress is very amazing; but by a peculiarly unlucky chance, admitted even by the men of science, this progress has not so far improved, but it has rather rendered worse, the [MASK] of the majority, that is to say, of the workingman.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Let us admit that the progress made in our day is noteworthy, marvellous, unusual; let us admit that we are fortunate mortals to live in such a remarkable epoch: but let us endeavor to appraise this progress, not on the basis of our self-satisfaction, but of that principle which defends itself with this progress,--the division of labor.
next_sentence: If the workingman can travel on the railway, instead of walking, still that same railway has burned down his forest, has carried off his grain under his very nose, and has brought his condition very near to slavery--to the capitalist.

question: We, the not only wealthy, but privileged and so-called cultivated persons, have [MASK] so far on the wrong road, that a great deal of determination, or a very great deal of suffering on the wrong road, is required, in order to bring us to our senses and to the acknowledgment of the lie in which we are living.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: If a man quails before the truth, and, on perceiving it, does not accept it, but does accept a lie for the truth, then he never will learn what he ought to do.
next_sentence: I have perceived the lie of our lives, thanks to the sufferings which the false path entailed upon me, and, having recognized the falseness of this path on which I stood, I have had the boldness to go at first in thought only--whither reason and conscience led me, without reflecting where they would bring me out.

question: To pass through all the ranks (tchini) in order to live for the purpose of passing the time, and to [MASK] an unlimited bank account, while the peasants, for whom this is not difficult, because of the invention of machinery, do the whole business ,--this is the complete formula of the idiotic creed of the people of our sphere in society.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: I behold in him myself and all my class.
next_sentence: When we inquire precisely what we are to do, surely, we ask nothing, but merely assert--only not in such good faith as the Most Serene Prince Blokhin, who has been promoted through all ranks, and lost his mind--that we do not wish to do any thing.

question: The character of labor is such, that the satisfaction of all a man's [MASK] demands that same succession of the sorts of work which renders work not a burden but a joy.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: A man who acknowledges his appointment to labor will naturally strive towards that rotation of labor which is peculiar to him, for the satisfaction of his inward requirements; and he can alter this labor in no other way than when he feels within himself an irresistible summons to some exclusive form of labor, and when the demands of other men for that labor are expressed.
next_sentence: Only a false creed, [Greek text which cannot be reproduced], to the effect that labor is a curse, could have led men to rid themselves of certain kinds of work; i.e., to the appropriation of the work of others, demanding the forced occupation with special labor of other people, which they call division of labor.

question: Evidently, they are rarely met with among men, in spite of the [MASK] that these men have not been selected from a single caste, but from mankind at large.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Glance backward into the past, and you will see that in the course of thousands of years, out of milliards of people, only half a score of Confucius', Buddhas, Solomons, Socrates, Solons, and Homers have been produced.
next_sentence: Evidently, these true teachers and artists and learned men, the purveyors of spiritual nourishment, are rare.

question: And all at once the [MASK] passed, and there was nothing left of him.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Every thing rested on him.
next_sentence: There was not even a hint of him, any more than if he had never existed.

question: Every other employment of man is only legal when it is directed to the satisfaction of this very first [MASK] of man; for the fulfilment of this duty constitutes the whole life of man.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The feeding, clothing, and taking care of himself and his family, constitute the satisfaction of the bodily demands and requirements; and doing the same for other people, constitutes the satisfaction of his spiritual requirements.
next_sentence: I had been so turned about by my previous life, this first and indubitable law of God or of nature is so concealed in our sphere of society, that the fulfilment of this law seemed to me strange, terrible, even shameful; as though the fulfilment of an eternal, unquestionable law, and not the departure from it, can be terrible, strange, and shameful.

question: We have only grown used to our false comprehension of the regulation of labor, because it seems to us that the shoemaker, the machinist, the [MASK], or the musician will be better off if he gets rid of the labor peculiar to man.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Only a false creed, [Greek text which cannot be reproduced], to the effect that labor is a curse, could have led men to rid themselves of certain kinds of work; i.e., to the appropriation of the work of others, demanding the forced occupation with special labor of other people, which they call division of labor.
next_sentence: Where there is no force exercised over the labor of others, or any false belief in the joy of idleness, not a single man will get rid of physical labor, necessary for the satisfaction of his requirements, for the sake of special work; because special work is not a privilege, but a sacrifice which man offers to inward pressure and to his brethren.

question: The thinker or the artist should [MASK] in company with the people, in order that he may find salvation or consolation.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The thinker or the artist will never sit calmly on Olympian heights, as we have become accustomed to represent them to ourselves.
next_sentence: Besides this, he will suffer because he is always and eternally in turmoil and agitation: he might decide and say that that which would confer welfare on men, would free them from suffering, would afford them consolation; but he has not said so, and has not presented it as he should have done; he has not decided, and he has not spoken; and to-morrow, possibly, it will be too late,--he will die.

question: There may be, and there are, sorcerers for whose services a demand makes itself felt, and for this purpose there are brought to them pancakes and flasks; but it is difficult to imagine the existence of sorcerers whose spells are [MASK] to every one, and who boldly demand that they shall be luxuriously supported because they exercise sorcery.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: It would be odd to see a shoemaker, who should consider that people were bound to feed him because he incessantly made boots which had been of no use to any one for a long time; but what shall we say of those men who make nothing,--who not only produce nothing that is visible, but nothing that is of use for people at large,--for whose wares there are no customers, and who yet demand, with the same boldness, on the ground of division of labor, that they shall be supplied with fine food and drink, and that they shall be dressed well?
next_sentence: And it is the same in our world.

question: The theory of evolution, to speak in simple language, merely asserts, that by chance, in an incalculably long [MASK] of time, out of any thing you like, any thing else that you like may develop.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: According to Moses' solution of the question (in the dispute with whom the entire significance of this theory lies), it appears that the diversity of the species of living creatures proceeded according to the will of God, and according to His almighty power; but according to the theory of evolution, it appears that the difference between living creatures arose by chance, and on account of varying conditions of heredity and surroundings, through an endless period of time.
next_sentence: This is no answer to the problem.

question: It is the same with [MASK] and science.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The Roman Republic was powerful, not because her citizens had the power to live a vicious life, but because among their number there were heroic citizens.
next_sentence: Art and science have bestowed much on mankind, but not because their followers formerly possessed on rare occasions (and now possess on every occasion) the possibility of getting rid of labor; but because there have been men of genius, who, without making use of these rights, have led mankind forward.

question: Men repudiate every science, the very substance of science ,--the definition of the destiny and the welfare of men ,--and this repudiation they designate as [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: And this "thus," men call the most accurate of scientific science.
next_sentence: Ever since men have existed, great minds have been born into their midst, which, in the conflict with reason and conscience, have put to themselves questions as to "what constitutes welfare,--the destiny and welfare, not of myself alone, but of every man?"

question: From the frivolity and the stupidity of this hypothesis, one would suppose that it would not [MASK] the attention of any one, and that it would sink into oblivion, like all the works of the same author which followed it; but it turned out quite otherwise.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: This fictitious law, this writer encompasses with mathematical formulae founded on nothing whatever; and then he launches it on the world.
next_sentence: The hack-writer who penned this treatise instantly becomes a scientific authority, and maintains himself upon that height for nearly half a century.

question: They [MASK] themselves by agriculture, as is natural to all men.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Men live.
next_sentence: One man has set up a blacksmith's forge, and repaired his plough; his neighbor comes to him, and asks him to mend his also, and promises him in return either work or money.

question: Men stand beside a constantly swelling spring of water, and are occupied with the problem of diverting it to one side, away from the thirsty people, and they assert that they are [MASK] this water, and that soon enough will be collected for all.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The result is, that some people make use of the labor of others; but that, if they shall make use of the labor of others for a very long period of time, and in still larger measure, then this wrongful distribution of wealth, i.e., the use of the labor of others, will come to an end.
next_sentence: But this water which has flowed, and which still flows unceasingly, and nourishes all mankind, not only is not the result of the activity of the men who, standing at its source, turn it aside, but this water flows and gushes out, in spite of the efforts of these men to obstruct its flow.

question: Without capital he is good for [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The technologist or the mechanic has to work with capital.
next_sentence: All his acquirements are such that for their display he requires capital, and the exploitation of the laboring- man on the largest scale; and--not to mention that he is trained to live, at the lowest, on from fifteen hundred to two thousand a year, and that, therefore, he cannot go to the country, where no one can give him such wages,--he is, by virtue of his very occupation, unfitted for serving the people.

question: Upon this doctrine is [MASK] the prevailing justification of our time.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Some people perform the muscular labor in societies; others, the mental labor."
next_sentence: Not long ago, their reigned in the learned, cultivated world, a moral philosophy, according to which it appeared that every thing which exists is reasonable; that there is no such thing as evil or good; and that it is unnecessary for man to war against evil, but that it is only necessary for him to display intelligence,--one man in the military service, another in the judicial, another on the violin.

question: At first it seems strange, that the theory of evolution can in any manner justify people in their evil [MASK]; and it seems as though the scientific theory of evolution has to deal only with facts, and that it does nothing else but observe facts.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Is not this same thing the cause of the confidence of men in positive critical-experimental science, and of the devout attitude of the crowd towards that which it preaches?
next_sentence: But this only appears to be the case.

question: Our botanists have discovered the cell, and in the cell [MASK], and in that protoplasm still something more, and in that atom yet another thing.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: And we have not tamed a single animal since biblical times, when all our animals were already domesticated; but the reindeer, the stag, the partridge, the heath-cock, all remain wild.
next_sentence: It is evident that these occupations will not end for a long time to come, because it is obvious that there can be no end to them, and therefore the scientist has no time to devote to those things which are necessary to the people.

question: It is more profitable in [MASK] the greatest possible quantity of calico, and boots in the shortest possible time.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: More profitable for whom?
next_sentence: But who will make these boots and this calico?

question: In the life and development of organisms, we find the following laws: the law of differentiation and [MASK], the law that every phenomenon is accompanied not by direct consequences alone, another law regarding the instability of type, and so on.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: And therefore, in order to find the law of life for man, it is necessary to study the laws of the life and the development of organisms.
next_sentence: All this seems very innocent; but it is only necessary to draw the deductions from all these laws, in order to immediately perceive that these laws incline in the same direction as the law of Malthus.

question: He requires an incalculable quantity of expensive preparations, instruments, drugs, and [MASK] apparatus.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: His fancied science is all so arranged, that he only knows how to heal those persons who do nothing.
next_sentence: He has studied with celebrities in the capitals, who only retain patients who can be cured in the hospital, or who, in the course of their cure, can purchase the appliances requisite for healing, and even go at once from the North to the South, to some baths or other.

question: There have [MASK] existed a true science, and a true art; but true science and art are not such because they called themselves by that name.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: But this water which has flowed, and which still flows unceasingly, and nourishes all mankind, not only is not the result of the activity of the men who, standing at its source, turn it aside, but this water flows and gushes out, in spite of the efforts of these men to obstruct its flow.
next_sentence: It always seems to those who claim at any given period to be the representatives of science and art, that they have performed, and are performing, and--most of all--that they will presently perform, the most amazing marvels, and that beside them there never has been and there is not any science or any art.

question: It always seems to those who [MASK] at any given period to be the representatives of science and art, that they have performed, and are performing, and--most of all--that they will presently perform, the most amazing marvels, and that beside them there never has been and there is not any science or any art.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: There have always existed a true science, and a true art; but true science and art are not such because they called themselves by that name.
next_sentence: Thus it seemed to the sophists, the scholastics, the alchemists, the cabalists, the talmudists; and thus it seems to our own scientific science, and to our art for the sake of art.

question: And in precisely the same manner, according to the measure of their folly, do they acquire self-conceit, which deprives them forever of all possibility of return to a simple life of toil, to a simple, clear, and universally [MASK] train of reasoning.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: But the principal thing is, that they pass their best years in getting disused to life; they grow accustomed to consider their position as justifiable; and they convert themselves physically into utterly useless parasites, and mentally they dislocate their brains and become mental eunuchs.
next_sentence: Division of labor always has existed in human communities, and will probably always exist; but the question for us lies not in the fact that it has existed, and that it will exist, but in this,--how are we to govern ourselves so that this division shall be right?

question: And it is not without reason that [MASK] has valued and still values them so highly.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Evidently, these true teachers and artists and learned men, the purveyors of spiritual nourishment, are rare.
next_sentence: But it now appears, that all these great factors in the science and art of the past are no longer of use to us.

question: It is evident that these occupations will not end for a [MASK] time to come, because it is obvious that there can be no end to them, and therefore the scientist has no time to devote to those things which are necessary to the people.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Our botanists have discovered the cell, and in the cell protoplasm, and in that protoplasm still something more, and in that atom yet another thing.
next_sentence: And therefore, again, from the time of Egyptian and Hebrew antiquity, when wheat and lentils had already been cultivated, down to our own times, not a single plant has been added to the food of the people, with the exception of the potato, and that was not obtained by science.

question: There are twenty-four [MASK] in the day; if we take away eight hours, sixteen remain.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The fact seemed startling: yet it is the most simple arithmetical calculation, which can be made by a seven-year-old boy, but which I had not been able to make up to this time.
next_sentence: If any man engaged in intellectual occupations devote five hours every day to his occupation, he will accomplish a fearful amount.

question: But with science, all this results [MASK], and therefore in a manner not to be doubted.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Moral philosophy also justified every sort of cruelty and harshness; but this resulted in a philosophical manner, and therefore wrongly.
next_sentence: How can we fail to accept so very beautiful a theory?

question: And yet all this is the province of [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: But science has never once thought of what axe or what hatchet is the most profitable to chop with, what saw is the most handy, what is the best way to mix bread, from what flour, how to set it, how to build and heat an oven, what food and drink, and what utensils, are the most convenient and advantageous under certain conditions, what mushrooms may be eaten, how to propagate them, and how to prepare them in the most suitable manner.
next_sentence: I am aware, that, according to its own definition, science ought to be useless, i.e., science for the sake of science; but surely this is an obvious evasion.

question: And we have [MASK] picture- galleries, and have studied different schools of art in detail; and we have so many symphonies and orchestras and operas, that it is becoming difficult even for us to listen to them.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: We have elevated a lot of people to the rank of great writers; we have picked these writers to pieces, and have written mountains of criticism, and criticism on the critics, and criticism on the critics of the critics.
next_sentence: But what have we added to the popular bylini [the epic songs], legends, tales, songs?

question: The feeding, clothing, and taking care of himself and his family, constitute the satisfaction of the bodily demands and requirements; and doing the same for other people, constitutes the satisfaction of his spiritual [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: In this one act, man receives--if the two things are to be separated--full satisfaction of the bodily and spiritual demands of his nature.
next_sentence: Every other employment of man is only legal when it is directed to the satisfaction of this very first duty of man; for the fulfilment of this duty constitutes the whole life of man.

question: For men who regard labor as the substance and the joy of life, the basis, the foundation of life will always be the struggle with nature ,--labor both agricultural and mechanical, and intellectual, and the establishment of communion between [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The members of the community took pity on him, and requested him to go to work in the fields.
next_sentence: Departure from one or from many of these varieties of labor, and the adoption of special labor, will then only occur when the man possessed of a special branch, and loving this work, and knowing that he can perform it better than others, sacrifices his own profit for the satisfaction of the direct demands made upon him.

question: because this [MASK] does not stand before them as it should stand.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: They can in no wise solve the problem, "What to do?"
next_sentence: The question must stand thus: "In what manner am I, a helpless, useless man, who, owing to the misfortune of my conditions, have wasted my best years of study in conning the scientific Talmud which corrupts soul and body, to correct this mistake, and learn to serve the people?"

question: The [MASK] of science is to serve the people.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: I am aware, that, according to its own definition, science ought to be useless, i.e., science for the sake of science; but surely this is an obvious evasion.
next_sentence: We have invented telegraphs, telephones, phonographs; but what advances have we effected in the life, in the labor, of the people?

question: If a man quails before the truth, and, on perceiving it, does not accept it, but does [MASK] a lie for the truth, then he never will learn what he ought to do.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: If a man who has long been travelling on this false path divines for himself, or is informed by some one, that his course is a mistaken one, but grows alarmed at the idea that he has wandered very far astray and tries to convince himself that he may, possibly, still strike into the right road, then he never will get into it.
next_sentence: We, the not only wealthy, but privileged and so-called cultivated persons, have advanced so far on the wrong road, that a great deal of determination, or a very great deal of suffering on the wrong road, is required, in order to bring us to our senses and to the acknowledgment of the lie in which we are living.

question: Does not this peculiar [MASK] fortune arise from the fact that man cannot and will not see his own hideousness?
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: How fortunate it is for us that we live in so peculiar an age, when that mental activity which calls itself science, not only does not err, but finds itself, as we are assured, in a remarkably flourishing condition!
next_sentence: Why is there nothing left of those sciences, and sophists, and Cabalists, and Talmudists, but words, while we are so exceptionally happy?

question: This doctrine had its rise not so very long--fifty [MASK]--ago.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: CHAPTER II.
next_sentence: Its principal founder was the French savant Comte.

question: He, as frequently happens, mistook his pet hypothesis for an axiom, and imagined that his whole theory was erected on the very [MASK] of foundations.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: This idea so pleased Comte, that upon it he began to erect a philosophical theory; and this theory so carried him away, that he utterly forgot that the point of departure for his theory was nothing more than a very pretty comparison, which was suitable for a fable, but which could by no means serve as the foundation for science.
next_sentence: According to his theory, it seemed that since humanity is an organism, the knowledge of what man is, and of what should be his relations to the world, was possible only through a knowledge of the features of this organism.

question: Moral philosophy also justified every sort of cruelty and harshness; but this resulted in a [MASK] manner, and therefore wrongly.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: And therefore, the unjust position in which we, the people who have freed ourselves from labor, find ourselves, must be regarded not from the point of view of common- sense and justice, but merely as an undoubted fact, confirming the universal law.
next_sentence: But with science, all this results scientifically, and therefore in a manner not to be doubted.

question: All that was the activity of the theological and metaphysical period ,--all that must be wiped out: but the true, the rational [MASK] began, say, fifty years ago, and in the course of those fifty years we have made so many great men, that there are about ten great men to every branch of science.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: And they have prepared so much of it, that it is no longer necessary to refer to the elder authorities, who have preceded them,--not only to the ancients, but to those much nearer to us.
next_sentence: And there have come to be so many sciences, that, fortunately, it is easy to make them.

question: This has taken [MASK] within my memory.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The old one has become useless; and the crowd has looked into the secret sanctuaries of the high priests, and has seen that there is nothing there, and that there has been nothing there, save very obscure and senseless words.
next_sentence: "But this arises," people of the present science will say, "from the fact that all that was the raving of the theological and metaphysical period; but now there exists positive, critical science, which does not deceive, since it is all founded on induction and experiment.

question: Both theories bore with them that idea which is precious to the crowd, that in the existent evil of human [MASK], men are not to blame, and that the existing order of things is that which should prevail; and the new theory was adopted by the throng with entire faith and unheard-of enthusiasm.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Two insecure theories, incapable of sustaining themselves on their feet, upheld each other, and acquired the semblance of stability.
next_sentence: And behold, on the strength of these two arbitrary and erroneous hypotheses, accepted as dogmas of belief, the new scientific doctrine was ratified.

question: The separate parts may die, but the whole [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
next_sentence: Exactly the case with the forest.

question: If, thanks to steam-engines and machines, the workingman can purchase inferior [MASK] at a cheap rate, on the other hand these engines and machines have deprived him of work at home, and have brought him into a state of abject slavery to the manufacturer.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: If the workingman can travel on the railway, instead of walking, still that same railway has burned down his forest, has carried off his grain under his very nose, and has brought his condition very near to slavery--to the capitalist.
next_sentence: If there are telephones and telescopes, poems, romances, theatres, ballets, symphonies, operas, picture-galleries, and so forth, on the other hand the life of the workingman has not been bettered by all this; for all of them, by the same unlucky chance, are inaccessible to him.

question: Hence it is necessary to find out whether we have made these weavers in accordance with an [MASK] law, or with some other.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: It would be well enough to speak thus if the colony of weavers had arisen by the free will of its member's; but we know that it is not thus formed of their initiative, but that we make it.
next_sentence: Men live.

question: They always decide it thus: that division of labor is right only when a special branch of man's activity is so [MASK] to men, that they, entreating him to serve them, voluntarily propose to support him in requital for that which he shall do for them.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: And reason and conscience decide the question for all men very simply, unanimously, and in a manner not to be doubted.
next_sentence: But, when a man can live from infancy to the age of thirty years on the necks of others, promising to do, when he shall have been taught, something extremely useful, for which no one asks him; and when, from the age of thirty until his death, he can live in the same manner, still merely on the promise to do something, for which there has been no request, this will not be division of labor (and, as a matter of fact, there is no such thing in our society), but it will be what it already is,--merely the appropriation, by force, of the toil of others; that same appropriation by force of the toil of others which the philosophers formerly designated by various names,--for instance, as indispensable forms of life,--but which scientific science now calls the organic division of labor.

question: It is impossible to investigate facts alone, because the facts which are subject to our investigation are [MASK] (in the definite sense of that word),--innumerable.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The men of contemporary science are very fond of saying, triumphantly and confidently, "We investigate only facts," imagining that these words contain some meaning.
next_sentence: Before we proceed to investigate facts, we must have a theory on the foundation of which these or those facts can be inquired into, i.e., selected from the incalculable quantity.

question: Hegelianism was, apparently, occupied only with its [MASK] constructions, and bore no relation to the life of mankind.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Exactly the same thing appeared to be the case with the Hegelian doctrine, in a greater degree, and also in the special instance of the Malthusian doctrine.
next_sentence: Precisely this seemed to be the case with the Malthusian theory.

question: And precisely this thing takes place in mankind and in [MASK] societies.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The queen lays the egg, the drone fructifies it; the bee works his whole life long.
next_sentence: And therefore, in order to find the law of life for man, it is necessary to study the laws of the life and the development of organisms.

question: Surely we have no justification for our privileged [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Surely we, the high priests of science and art, are ourselves worthless deceivers, possessing much less right to our position than the most crafty and depraved priests.
next_sentence: The priests had a right to their position: they declared that they taught the people life and salvation.

question: The technologist, the physician, the teacher, the artist, the author, should, in virtue of their very [MASK], it would seem, serve the people.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The falsity of the whole direction of our arts and sciences is more striking and more apparent in precisely those very branches, which, it would seem, should, from their very nature, be of use to the people, and which, in consequence of their false attitude, seem rather injurious than useful.
next_sentence: And, what then?

question: If there are [MASK] and telescopes, poems, romances, theatres, ballets, symphonies, operas, picture-galleries, and so forth, on the other hand the life of the workingman has not been bettered by all this; for all of them, by the same unlucky chance, are inaccessible to him.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: If, thanks to steam-engines and machines, the workingman can purchase inferior calico at a cheap rate, on the other hand these engines and machines have deprived him of work at home, and have brought him into a state of abject slavery to the manufacturer.
next_sentence: So that, on the whole (and even men of science admit this), up to the present time, all these remarkable discoveries and products of science and art have certainly not ameliorated the condition of the workingman, if, indeed, they have not made it worse.

question: Art and science have bestowed much on mankind, but not because their followers formerly [MASK] on rare occasions (and now possess on every occasion) the possibility of getting rid of labor; but because there have been men of genius, who, without making use of these rights, have led mankind forward.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: It is the same with art and science.
next_sentence: The class of learned men and artists, which has advanced, on the fictitious basis of a division of labor, its demands to the right of using the labors of others, cannot co-operate in the success of true science and true art, because a lie cannot bring forth the truth.

question: [MASK] because it is its property to be always thus, does mankind so highly prize this activity.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Scientific and artistic activity, in its real sense, is only fruitful when it knows no rights, but recognizes only obligations.
next_sentence: If men really were called to the service of others through artistic work, they would see in that work only obligation, and they would fulfil it with toil, with privations, and with self-abnegation.

question: Thus it turned out, that employment in those physical labors which are indispensable to me, as they are to every man, not only did not interfere with my [MASK] activity, but was an indispensable condition of the usefulness, worth, and cheerfulness of that activity.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: And these demands called into play only good nature, and therefore the usefulness and the joy of my special labor.
next_sentence: The bird is so constructed, that it is indispensable that it should fly, walk, peek, combine; and when it does all this, it is satisfied and happy,--then it is a bird.

question: Men need not work in order to eat, and [MASK] need not bear children.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: We have changed all that.
next_sentence: A ragged peasant roams the Krapivensky district.

question: Some people perform the muscular labor in societies; others, the mental [MASK]. ''
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: If some have in superabundance, and others in want, this arises not from the will of God, not because the empire is a form of manifestation of personality, but because in societies, as in organisms, division of labor becomes indispensable for life as a whole.
next_sentence: Upon this doctrine is founded the prevailing justification of our time.

question: We have arranged for ourselves a life that is repugnant both to the moral and the physical nature of man, and all the powers of our intelligence we concentrate upon assuring man that this is the most natural [MASK] possible.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The same thing has happened with us, but with this difference: that it was impossible to deceive the horses in any way, and they were kept in bonds to prevent their getting out; but we are kept in an unnatural position that is equally injurious to us, by deceits which have entangled us, and which hold us like chains.
next_sentence: Every thing which we call culture,--our sciences, art, and the perfection of the pleasant thing's of life,--all these are attempts to deceive the moral requirements of man; every thing that is called hygiene and medicine, is an attempt to deceive the natural physical demands of human nature.

question: Where there has been true science, [MASK] has always been its exponent.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: And the same with art.
next_sentence: Ever since men have been in existence, they have been in the habit of deducing, from all pursuits, the expressions of various branches of learning concerning the destiny and the welfare of man, and the expression of this knowledge has been art in the strict sense of the word.

question: If the [MASK] lies in manufacturing as much calico and as many pins as possible, then this is so.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Then how can this be more profitable for men?
next_sentence: But the point concerns men and their welfare.

question: Surely we, the high priests of science and art, are ourselves worthless deceivers, possessing much less right to our position than the most crafty and depraved [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Surely we are nothing else than the scribes and Pharisees, who sit in Moses' seat, and who have taken the keys of the kingdom of heaven, and will neither go in ourselves, nor permit others to go in.
next_sentence: Surely we have no justification for our privileged position.

question: The peasants will [MASK] to all that . ''
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: To the question, whether he does not wish to work, he always replies proudly: "I am much obliged.
next_sentence: When you tell him that the peasants do not wish to work, either, he answers: "It is not difficult for the peasant."

question: The same thing has happened with us, but with this difference: that it was impossible to deceive the horses in any way, and they were kept in bonds to prevent their getting out; but we are kept in an unnatural position that is equally injurious to us, by deceits which have entangled us, and which hold us like [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: The horses stood there until they were good for nothing.
next_sentence: We have arranged for ourselves a life that is repugnant both to the moral and the physical nature of man, and all the powers of our intelligence we concentrate upon assuring man that this is the most natural life possible.

question: It was floating in the air; it was expressed in newspaper and periodical articles, in historical and judicial [MASK], in novels, in treatises, in art, in sermons, in conversation.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: When I began my career, Hegelianism was the foundation of every thing.
next_sentence: The man who was not acquainted with Hegal had no right to speak.

question: There will be no sleek, plump, self-satisfied thinkers and [MASK].
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: Not of this description will be the thinker and artist who is reared in an establishment where, apparently, they manufacture the learned man or the artist (but in point of fact, they manufacture destroyers of science and of art), who receives a diploma and a certificate, who would be glad not to think and not to express that which is imposed on his soul, but who cannot avoid doing that to which two irresistible forces draw him,--an inward prompting, and the demand of men.
next_sentence: Spiritual activity, and its expression, which are actually necessary to others, are the most burdensome of all man's avocations; a cross, as the Gospels phrase it.

question: All the inventions of [MASK] and hygiene for persons of our sphere are much the same as though a mechanic should hit upon the idea of heating a steam- boiler which was not working, and should shut all the valves so that the boiler should not burst.
source_info: On the Significance of Science and Art by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: On the Significance of Science and Art
prev_sentence: It turned out that all these devices of the human mind for the agreeable arrangement of the physical existence of idle persons are precisely analogous to those artful contrivances which people might invent for the production in vessels hermetically sealed, by means of mechanical arrangements, of evaporation, and plants, of the air best fitted for breathing, when all that is needed is to open the window.
next_sentence: Only one thing is needed, instead of all these extremely complicated devices for pleasure, for comfort, and for medical and hygienic preparations, intended to save people from their spiritual and bodily ailments, which swallow up so much labor,--to fulfil the law of life; to do that which is proper not only to man, but to the animal; to fire off the charge of energy taken win in the shape of food, by muscular exertion; to speak in plain language, to earn one's bread.

question: The interpretation is not new in theory, but never before has it been carried out with so much zeal, so much determination, so much sincerity, and, granting the premises, with logic so unanswerable, as in this beautiful [MASK] of faith.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: He bases his conclusions on a direct and literal interpretation of the teachings of Jesus as expressed in the Sermon on the Mount.
next_sentence: How movingly does he depict the doubts and fears of the searcher after the better life; how impressive his earnest inquiry for truth; how inspiring his confidence in the natural goodness, as opposed to the natural depravity of man; how convincing his argument that the doctrine of Jesus is simple, practicable, and conducive to the highest happiness; how terrifying his enumeration of the sufferings of "the martyrs to the doctrine of the world"; how pitiless his arraignment of the Church for its complacent indifference to the welfare of humanity here in this present stage of existence; how sublime his prophecy of the golden age when men shall dwell together in the bonds of love, and sin and suffering shall be no more the common lot of mankind!

question: After each reference of this sort had thus far come a commandment, and each commandment had been important and [MASK] in meaning; it ought to be so now.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: But as I had found a simple, precise, and practical meaning in each of the passages beginning with a reference to the ancient law, I anticipated a similar experience here.
next_sentence: The closing words of the passage, repeated by Luke, which are to the effect that God makes no distinction of persons, but lavishes his gifts upon all, and that we, following his precepts, ought to regard all men as equally worthy, and to do good to all,--these words were clear; they seemed to me to be a confirmation and exposition of some definite law--but what was this law?

question: This singular phenomenon is due to the false [MASK] which has penetrated into the very marrow of humanity.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: Believers and sceptics who concern themselves so little with the problem how to live, how to make use of the reason with which we are endowed, ask why our earthly life is not what they imagine it ought to be, and when it will become what they wish.
next_sentence: The effects of the knowledge of good and evil, which man so unhappily acquired in paradise, do not seem to have been very lasting; for, neglecting the truth that life is only a solution of the contradictions between animal instincts and reason, he stolidly refrains from applying his reason to the discovery of the historical laws that govern his animal nature.

question: What once seemed to me the most delightful [MASK] in the world, an existence made up of dainty, aesthetic pleasures and passions, is now revolting to me.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion

prev_sentence: He who understands this will not ask to be strengthened in his faith, but will work out his salvation without the need of any exhortation.

question: It is a dilemma from which no man can [MASK].

prev_sentence: Again I must choose.

question: We must rid ourselves of the savage prejudice which leads us to think that a man who has an income from a place under the government, from landed property, or from stocks and bonds, is in a natural and happy position because he is [MASK] from the necessity of work.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.

prev_sentence: We must get back to that point of view natural to all men who are not fallen, that work, and not idleness, is the indispensable condition of happiness for every human being; that man cannot, in fact, refrain from work.

question: As fire cannot extinguish fire, so evil cannot suppress [MASK].

title: My Religion
prev_sentence: The advance of humanity towards righteousness is due, not to the tyrants, but to the martyrs.

title: My Religion

question: Men struggled for the [MASK], for objects which are necessary to them; then they arrived at the division of goods, and called this property; finding that this arrangement, although difficult to establish, was best, they maintained ownership.

title: My Religion
prev_sentence: The reasonable activity of man, from his earliest existence, has been applied to the search for what is best among the contradictions that envelop human life.

question: This exception, which throws the guilt of marital infidelity entirely upon the woman is, in general, strange and unexpected; but here, in relation to the context, it is simply [MASK], for even the very doubtful meaning which might otherwise be attributed to it is wholly destroyed.

question: They understood everything but the one significant truth in the wise man's teachings ,--that they must work out for themselves their own peace and happiness there on the farm, which they took for a [MASK] abode thinking all the time of the better life they were to possess elsewhere.

title: My Religion

next_sentence: Here is the origin of the strange declaration that the precepts of the wise man were admirable, even divine, but that they were difficult to practise.

question: But he who lives this way cannot affirm that he lives a [MASK] life.
