prev_sentence: We may live a purely animal life according to the doctrine of the world, without recognizing any controlling motive more binding than the rules of established authority.
next_sentence: Before affirming that we live a reasonable life, we must determine what is the doctrine of the life which we regard as reasonable.

question: Jesus taught [MASK] to lift on high the light of reason.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: Now, Jesus first taught men to believe in the light, and that the light is within themselves.
next_sentence: He taught them to live, guiding their actions by this light, and to do nothing contrary to reason.

question: They decided that the farm was only a temporary dwelling-place, and that it was not worth while to try to [MASK] well there; the important thing was not to be cheated out of the other life promised them elsewhere.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: And they imagined that the wise man had condemned their life on the farm, and had promised them another and a better life somewhere else.
next_sentence: This is the only way in which we can explain the strange conduct of the people on the farm, of whom some believed that the wise man was God, and others that he was a man of wisdom, but all continued to live as before in defiance of the wise man's words.

question: The entire written law, he says, may be reduced to this expression of the eternal law, and by these words he abrogated the eternal [MASK].
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: 12), he speaks of the written law.
next_sentence: When he says, "The law and the prophets were until John" (Luke xvi.

question: Men fought with one another for the possession of [MASK], they abandoned their children; then they found it was best that each should have his own family; and although it was difficult to sustain a family, they maintained the family, as they did ownership and many other things.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: Men struggled for the soil, for objects which are necessary to them; then they arrived at the division of goods, and called this property; finding that this arrangement, although difficult to establish, was best, they maintained ownership.
next_sentence: As soon as they discover that a thing is best, however difficult of attainment, men do it.

question: But he did not say that those who followed his doctrine would suffer more than those who followed the world's doctrine; on the contrary, he said that those who followed the world's [MASK] would be wretched, and that those who followed his doctrine would have joy and peace.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: He said that his disciples would be persecuted for his doctrine, and that they must bear the persecutions of the world with resolution.
next_sentence: Jesus did not teach salvation by faith in asceticism or voluntary torture, but he taught us a way of life which, while saving us from the emptiness of the personal life, would give us less of suffering and more of joy.

question: Now it is difficult, because in [MASK] it we are obliged to deprive ourselves of many things that we have hitherto enjoyed.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: And yet we say that the doctrine of Jesus is admirable, but impossible of practice, because it is difficult!
next_sentence: Have we never heard that it is far more to our advantage to endure difficulties and privations than to satisfy all our desires?

question: The matter would not be so serious if the men, in [MASK] aside the unskilful pilot, did not forget that without a pilot they are likely to take a wrong course.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: Then they discover that the new pilot is utterly useless, and they mock at him, and drive him from his place.
next_sentence: But so it is with our Christian society.

question: We decide in advance that the [MASK] order which controls our existence, and which is abolished by these words, is the superior law of humanity.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: It would seem that before correcting them one ought to understand them; now this is exactly what no one wishes to do.
next_sentence: For my part, I consider our social order to be neither wise nor sacred; and that is why I have understood this commandment when others have not.

question: Any doctrine teaching men how they should [MASK] instructs them only as to what is best for each.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: It is natural to each human being to do what seems to him best.
next_sentence: If we show men what they have to do to attain what is best for each, how can they say that they would like to do it, but that it is impossible of attainment?

question: Jesus, then, must have thought of the [MASK] institutions which condemned him and his disciples; which have condemned and continue to condemn millions of men.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: He said of himself that he should be condemned by a tribunal, and he showed what the attitude toward judges ought to be.
next_sentence: Jesus saw the wrong and faced it.

question: [MASK] who have received a benefit act far otherwise.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: If a man sets a value upon his rights to life, if he keeps a reckoning with the Overruling Power from whom he has received life, he proves simply that he does not understand the meaning of life.
next_sentence: The laborers employed in the vineyard were found by the householder idle and unhappy; they did not possess life in the proper meaning of the term.

question: Jesus has shown me that the first temptation destructive of happiness is enmity toward [MASK], anger against them.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: I can no longer work for the destruction of my happiness, and in this determination, and in this alone, is the substance of my religion.
next_sentence: I cannot refuse to believe this, and so I cannot willingly remain at enmity with others.

question: Is not the [MASK] system like a great prison where each inmate is restricted to association with a few fellow-convicts?
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: For kings and emperors, the circle is still more narrow.
next_sentence: Finally, the fifth condition of happiness is bodily health.

question: But [MASK] this existence is in itself attractive?
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: Another continues the same task, sacrifices his life to this same Moloch, and then dies also, without realizing for what he has lived.
next_sentence: Compare it with what men have always called happiness, and you will see that it is hideous.

question: Why do you [MASK] up your children in a way that will force them to lead an existence which you find worthless?
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: Why do you abandon agriculture, which you love, for work in factories and mills, which you despise?
next_sentence: Why do you do this?"

question: The two substantial sources of faith, the [MASK] that governs life, and the explanation of the meaning of life, are regarded as of very unequal value.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: On the contrary, we find the extraordinary conviction that they are superfluous; that religion is nothing more than a few words about God and a future life, and a few ceremonies very useful for the salvation of the soul according to some, and good for nothing according to others; but that life happens of itself and has no need of any fundamental rule, and that we have only to do what we are told to do.
next_sentence: The first is considered as of very little importance, and as having no relation to faith whatever; the second, as the explanation of a bygone state of existence, or as made up of speculations concerning the historical development of life, is considered as of great significance.

question: This is why [MASK] will never be left without support.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: People breed and train and care for oxen, and a man, as a beast of burden, is much more useful than an ox, as the tariff of the slave-mart shows.
next_sentence: Man is not in the world to work for himself; he is in the world to work for others, and the laborer is worthy of his hire.

question: He told them that they could not believe because they were not of his sheep; that is, they did not follow the road he had [MASK] out.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: Jesus explained that this was impossible, and he told them why it was impossible.
next_sentence: He explained why some believed, and why others did not believe, and he told them what faith really was.

question: Only a chimerical idea, mistaking reality for what does not [MASK], and taking the non-existent for reality, could lead men to deny the possibility of practising that which by their own avowal would be for their true welfare.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: In this marvellous argument that the doctrine of Jesus is admirable, and that its practice would give the world true happiness, but that men are weak and sinful, that they would do the best and do the worst, and so cannot do the best,--in this strange plea there is an evident misapprehension; there is something else besides defective reasoning; there is also a chimerical idea.
next_sentence: The chimerical idea which has reduced men to this condition is that of the dogmatic Christian religion, as it is taught through the various catechisms, to all who profess the Christianity of the Church.

question: This book of devotion, spread broadcast in an enormous number of copies, awakening doubts in the minds of the most unlearned people, [MASK] me to thinking.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: As I have said, I not only had sought to avoid censure of the religion of the Church; I had done my best to see only its most favorable side; and knowing its academic literature from beginning to end, I had paid no attention whatever to its popular literature.
next_sentence: The contents of the book seemed to me so entirely pagan, so wholly out of accord with Christianity, that I could not believe it to be the deliberate purpose of the Church to propagate such a doctrine.

question: From morning till night these thousands of [MASK], the greater portion of them starving and in rags, tramped angrily through the mud, venting their hatred in abusive epithets and acts of violence.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: For the distance of half a verst the vehicle forced its way through a compact crowd which quickly reformed its ranks.
next_sentence: The same sight may be seen in all the market-places of Moscow.

question: Jesus [MASK] of this misapprehension by means of a parable illustrating true faith.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: This disposition of mind is common to us all; it is contrary to the meaning of the doctrine of Jesus, and yet we are astonished at our lack of faith.
next_sentence: Faith cannot come of confidence in his words; faith can come only of a consciousness of our condition; faith is based only upon the dictates of reason as to what is best to do in a given situation.

question: If a man will not seize upon his only means of safety, it is plain that he does not understand his [MASK].
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: What is the meaning of this?
next_sentence: How can a Christian who professes to believe in the divinity of Jesus and of his doctrine, whatever may be the meaning that he attaches thereto, say that he wishes to believe, and that he cannot believe?

question: It is plain also that a [MASK] purpose runs through them all, a purpose which only in the author's latest production finds full expression.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: Pierre Besushkof, one of the three heroes of War and Peace, has, rightly or wrongly, long been regarded as in some respects an autobiographical study, but the personal note is always clearly perceptible in Count Tolstoi's writings, if we are to believe the reports of the enthusiastic purveyors of literary information who have made known some of their many attractive qualities.
next_sentence: There are hints of it in Childhood and Youth; in War and Peace, and in a subsequent romance, Anna Karenin, it becomes very distinct.

question: And all these tens of thousands of unhappy people sleep in hovels, and subsist upon strong drink and wretched [MASK].
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: All these people have forsaken houses, lands, parents, wives, and children; they have renounced all the comforts of life, and they have come to the cities to acquire that which according to the gospel of the world is indispensable to every one.
next_sentence: But aside from this class, all, from factory workman, cab-driver, sewing girl, and lorette, to merchant and government official, all endure the most painful and abnormal conditions without being able to acquire what, according to the doctrine of the world, is indispensable to each.

question: Seek among all these men, from beggar to millionaire, one who is contented with his lot, and you will not find one such in a [MASK].
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: But aside from this class, all, from factory workman, cab-driver, sewing girl, and lorette, to merchant and government official, all endure the most painful and abnormal conditions without being able to acquire what, according to the doctrine of the world, is indispensable to each.
next_sentence: Each one spends his strength in pursuit of what is exacted by the doctrine of the world, and of what he is unhappy not to possess, and scarcely has he obtained one object of his desires when he strives for another, and still another, in that infinite labor of Sisyphus which destroys the lives of men.

question: To [MASK] for self alone, for the animal life, is not reasonable.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: Life is life, and we must make the best of it.
next_sentence: And so men, from their earliest existence, have sought for some reason for living aside from the gratification of their own desires; they live for their children, for their families, for their nation, for humanity, for all that does not die with the personal life.

question: The reasonable activity of man has always been--it could not be otherwise--to light by the torch of [MASK] his progress toward beatitude.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: The doctrine of Confucius teaches the perfecting of the individual; Judaism, personal fidelity to an alliance with God; Buddhism, how to escape from a life governed by animal instincts; Socrates taught the perfecting of the individual through reason; the Stoics recognized the independence of reason as the sole basis of the true life.
next_sentence: Philosophy tells us that free-will is an illusion, and then boasts of the boldness of such a declaration.

question: They were in this case of [MASK] assistance to me.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: And desiring to find an explanation of this rule, which troubled me through its very simplicity, I consulted the commentators.
next_sentence: The commentators all found in these words a confirmation of the third commandment of Moses,--not to swear by the name of the Lord; but, in addition to this, they explained that this commandment of Jesus against an oath was not always obligatory, and had no reference whatever to the oath which citizens are obliged to take before the authorities.

question: And in like [MASK] also reverence that which is best in thyself; and this is of the same kind as that.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: [13] Marcus Aurelius says: "Reverence that which is best in the      universe; and this is that which makes use of all things and      directs all things.
next_sentence: For in      thyself, also, that which makes use of everything else, is this,      and thy life is directed by this."

question: He [MASK] that his disciples would be persecuted for his doctrine, and that they must bear the persecutions of the world with resolution.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: He had pity upon men, who to him were like sheep without a shepherd.
next_sentence: But he did not say that those who followed his doctrine would suffer more than those who followed the world's doctrine; on the contrary, he said that those who followed the world's doctrine would be wretched, and that those who followed his doctrine would have joy and peace.

question: The basis of faith is the meaning that we derive from life, the meaning that [MASK] whether we look upon life as important and good, or trivial and corrupt.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: This incapacity to understand the substance of faith explains the strange moral state of men, who, acknowledging that they ought to live in accordance with the doctrine of Jesus, endeavor to live in opposition to this doctrine, conformably to their belief that the personal life is a sovereign good.
next_sentence: Faith is the appreciation of good and of evil.

question: To have the faith that will save them from perishing, they must cease to do what will [MASK] them to perdition, and they must begin to do something for their own safety; they must grasp the rope of safety.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: But this is impossible.
next_sentence: Now this is exactly what they do not wish to do; they wish to persuade themselves that they will not perish, although they see their comrades perishing one after another before their very eyes.

question: No one (with the exception of foolish parents) takes the trouble to care for lazy people, because lazy people are of no use to any one, not [MASK] to themselves; as for the workers, the most selfish and cruel of men will contribute to their welfare.
source_info: My Religion by Tolstoy, Lev N.
title: My Religion
prev_sentence: The objection concerning the possibility of practising the doctrine of Jesus, that if men do not acquire something for themselves and have wealth in reserve no one will take care of their families, is true, but it is true only in regard to idle and useless and obnoxious people such as make up the majority of our opulent classes.
next_sentence: People breed and train and care for oxen, and a man, as a beast of burden, is much more useful than an ox, as the tariff of the slave-mart shows.
